Here, we report the synthesis of neon hydrate, in which neon atoms are enclathrated in the channels of ice II. This is the first observation of a noble gas hydrate to our knowledge. The guest Ne atoms have substantial freedom of movement owing to the lack of direct bonding between guest molecules and host lattices. Molecular dynamics simulation confirms that the resolved structure where Ne atoms dissolved in ice II is thermodynamically stable at 480 MPa and 260 K. Hilbert spaces and their operators are the mathematical foundation of quantum mechanics. They are usually introduced via a complex vector space with a scalar product. We show that this is not necessary: The axioms of Hilbert spaces can be reformulated purely categorically, without using complex numbers or scalar products. This has the advantage that the axioms are much simpler and also that they apply to more general structures that might be of interest in quantum foundations. Our work is also significant for computer science, where categorical quantum mechanics is used to model quantum computation. Our categorical formulation is more concise and has a different emphasis compared to the existing analytical formulations. It also provides a different perspective on the relation between quantum mechanics and classical probability theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of over 2,000 microscopic parasites with a complex life cycle that involves both invertebrate and vertebrate hosts. The origin of myxozoans has been a mystery, but a close relationship with the Cnidaria, a phylum that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the myxozoan polar capsule is similar to the stinging structures of cnidarians. We show that myxozoans are cnidarians, and a sister group to the more reduced parasite Polypodium hydriforme. Myxozoan genomes are extremely small, and gene ontology analyses indicate that categories related to development, cell differentiation, and cell–cell communication are depleted. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasite was accompanied by an extreme reduction in genome size and gene content.

The IFN-signaling pathway is a major antiviral defense mechanism in our body. Several viruses have evolved strategies to interfere with IFN signaling to establish infection. Here we show that SARS-CoV-2 Orf6 targets the nuclear pore complex (NPC) to disrupt nuclear import and antagonize IFN signaling. This is an important finding because it demonstrates that a viral protein can alter NPC function to gain access to the nucleus and inhibit IFN signaling. This strategy may be used by other viruses that encode similar viral proteins. Therefore, understanding how viruses interfere with the IFN-signaling pathway and NPC function is critical for the development of strategies to combat viral infection. This is particularly relevant in the case of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2.

Voltage-gated proton (Hv1) channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels.

We quantify the impacts of rising temperatures on maize yield variability in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. Absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, maize yield variability is projected to increase substantially in most maize-producing regions under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This higher yield variability will lead to more frequent and severe maize production losses in the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports. Presently, the probability that these countries have simultaneous production losses in any given year is virtually zero. Under 4 °C warming, this probability increases to 86%. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also portend rising instability in global grain trade.

The coexistence of many competing species is a central problem in ecology. For large mammalian herbivores (LMH), coexistence may depend on partitioning of food resources, which can be inferred from diet composition. However, because comprehensive diet analysis is difficult, it is not known how many species-level plant taxa are consumed by different LMH species, or how this varies across species that differ in feeding strategy and body size. We used DNA metabarcoding to analyze 37,782 sequences from 1,032 fresh dung samples to quantify the breadth and overlap of diets for seven abundant African LMH species. Our results show that even sympatric species that are similar in feeding strategy and body size have highly distinct diets, which are underpinned by fine-grained partitioning of plant species. These findings have implications for understanding the structure and diversity of LMH communities.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses between March 28 and April 4, 2020, to better understand the impact of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) on small businesses and inform policy responses. The survey was fielded during a period of rapidly escalating COVID-19 cases and disruptions to economic activity. As such, the survey likely underestimates the negative impacts of the pandemic. Nevertheless, several themes emerged. First, mass layoffs and closures had already occurred—just a few weeks into the crisis. Second, many small businesses are financially fragile. Finally, businesses had widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of COVID-related disruptions. These beliefs strongly influenced business closures. We also experimentally test the impact of different relief programs on take-up rates and business resilience.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern due to its persistence and potential impact on marine life. However, the magnitude of this pollution and its impact on the global distribution of floating debris are still poorly understood. We show a worldwide distribution of plastic on the surface of the open ocean, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of each of the five subtropical gyres with comparable density. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected. We hypothesize that a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered, removes a significant amount of plastic debris from the surface of the ocean. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

We determined interstellar cosmic ray exposure ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains from the Murchison meteorite. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. We also show that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The large difference in nuclear recoil loss of cosmic ray spallation products 3He and 21Ne enabled us to estimate that the irradiated objects in the interstellar medium were up to 30 times larger than the analyzed grains. These results also imply that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun.

We reconstructed the global fishing fleet from 1950 to 2015, disaggregating data into three sectors: artisanal (unpowered/powered) and industrial. The global fishing fleet doubled in size between 1950 and 2015, driven by a substantial expansion of the motorized fleet, particularly, of the powered-artisanal fleet. Alongside an expansion of the fleets, the effective catch per unit of effort has consistently decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective catch per unit of effort of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. We show that 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years.

The evolution of all forms of cooperative breeding and domestication represent evolutionary solutions to the problem of the high energetic cost of reproduction. Here, we show that these evolutionary solutions do, in fact, increase reproductive output and that the magnitude of the increase is comparable among different primate species that practice different forms of provisioning. We also show that the effect of cooperative breeding on fertility is comparable to the effect of domestication. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This has important implications for understanding the evolution of reproductive strategies. Future work should focus on understanding the proximate mechanisms that limit reproductive output in wild mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a fatal neurodegenerative disorder with no available treatment. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. The inflammatory protease caspase-1 has been implicated in the mechanisms that promote aggregation of α-syn in vitro and in neuronal cell models of α-syn toxicity. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and mediate neuroprotection in a transgenic mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a rationale for the development of VX-765 or similar compounds for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelial layer of the blood vessels controls cardiovascular function. It receives information from multiple sources and integrates the data to coordinate vascular responses. This is achieved by a highly developed but poorly understood communication system operating between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The data reveal that the network has a scale-free and small-world topology. The small-world configuration confers dynamic endothelial properties including high signal-propagation speed, stability, and a high degree of synchronizability. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for timely and accurate data on COVID-19 cases, deaths, and hospitalizations, as well as auxiliary data on COVID-19–relevant behaviors and conditions. The COVIDcast API provides daily updates on COVID-19 cases, deaths, and hospitalizations, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. All of the data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying software packages.

In this study, we have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We show that a Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position in KcsA, KCa3.1, and KCNQ1 abolishes C-type inactivation gating and inverts the allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter, and opening of the activation gate expands the channel’s selectivity filter). We also provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides new tools to study the role of the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels.

The herbivore digestive tract is a highly complex ecosystem that supports a diverse range of microorganisms. Anaerobic gut fungi are a minor component of the gut microbiome, but they are efficient at degrading plant biomass and have been shown to increase fiber digestibility in their hosts. Here, we show that anaerobic gut fungi produce a diverse range of natural products, including antibiotics, which could contribute to regulating the composition of the gut microbiome. The natural products cataloged here could be further developed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This work also demonstrates the utility of combining multiple 'omics' approaches to characterize the natural products of fungi. The approach taken here could be applied to other poorly characterized fungal species.

The establishment of dominance hierarchies is a ubiquitous feature of social groups. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Elucidating the neurobiological mechanisms that underlie the link between anxiety and social competence may have important implications for the understanding and treatment of anxiety-related social disorders, such as autism spectrum disorder and social anxiety disorder.

This paper develops a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize optimal composite structures to achieve arbitrary prescribed mechanical responses under large deformation. The synthesized structures are organically shaped and composed of multiple materials with distinct properties that are seamlessly integrated to achieve the target behavior. While complex in geometry and material heterogeneity, the structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The nonlinear behavior of the synthesized structures can also serve as a library for digital synthesis of nonlinear mechanical systems.

The expression of the gamma- and delta-globin genes in human erythroblasts is tightly regulated in a developmental fashion. The expression of the gamma- and delta-globin genes is silenced during late proerythroblast maturation, while the adult beta-globin gene is turned on. The cause of this change is unknown. Here we show that overexpression of IGF2BP1 in human erythroid progenitor cells can cause a nearly complete reversal of the adult pattern of hemoglobin expression toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This is achieved by reduced expression of the transcriptional repressor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. These results have implications for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell disease.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated cell death that is driven by reactive oxygen species and iron. It is regulated by many signaling pathways, including the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway, which is frequently mutated or hyperactivated in human cancer. Here we show that activation of PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling confers resistance to ferroptosis. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also show that SREBP1-mediated induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1) is required for ferroptosis resistance. SCD1 produces monounsaturated fatty acids, which are essential for maintaining the integrity of the cell membrane during ferroptosis. Finally, we show that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models of PI3K-mutated breast cancer and PTEN-defective prostate cancer.

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure, and vascular remodeling is a major driver of heart failure. Vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) undergo remodeling in hypertension, characterized by changes in gene expression and Ca2+ signaling machinery. Store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) is activated in VSMCs in hypertension and promotes fibro-proliferative gene programs. Here, we show that three major classes of Ca2+ channel blockers for hypertension act on the endoplasmic reticulum stromal-interacting molecule (STIM) proteins to activate SOCE. This causes VSMC remodeling in vitro and in vivo. We also show that patients with cardiovascular disease treated with these blockers have higher risk of heart failure. Our findings suggest that these drugs should be used with caution in patients with advanced hypertension. We suggest that STIM/ORAI may be a target for drugs to treat hypertension and heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) halted clearcutting on federal land in the Pacific Northwest, USA. We used bird surveys, forest data, and land-ownership maps to evaluate the NWFP’s influence. Declines of older-forest–associated birds accelerated after the NWFP, likely due to losses of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. Although the NWFP stabilized the area of early-seral ecosystems on federal land, this was not the case in two ecoregions, where declines in early-seral bird populations continued. These findings suggest that the NWFP has not yet halted declines of older forests or reversed declines of early-seral ecosystems. Continued prioritization of older forests and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure are needed to reverse biodiversity declines.

The development of new antibiotics is urgently required to combat the growing problem of antibiotic resistance. In this study, we present a rational design approach to improve acylide antibiotics, which are a promising new class of antibiotics. The best candidates were tested experimentally, showing that our design strategy led to compounds that are up to 56 times more active against resistant bacteria than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds are active against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our results demonstrate that computational approaches can be used to drastically accelerate the drug development process and to improve the activity of new antibiotics.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems, such as image classification and image segmentation. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. The proposed network architecture achieves accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

This study provides a 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa, derived from a sediment core. We show that Lake Malawi has dried up completely at least 24 times during the Late Quaternary, including 15 times when water levels were more than 400 m lower than today. We observe a dramatic shift in hydroclimate regime at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (800,000 years ago), which is consistent with far-field climate forcing. We also show that periods of high lake level are coincident with times of high eccentricity, supporting a strong orbital forcing. Finally, we highlight the impact of these large-scale changes in hydroclimate on the evolution of the endemic cichlid fish species flock in Lake Malawi. These findings have important implications for understanding the sensitivity of continental hydroclimate to far-field forcing.

The use of light-emitting electronic devices for reading, communication, and entertainment has become widespread, particularly among young adults. However, the impact of such devices on sleep and circadian rhythms is not known. Here we show that the use of light-emitting devices immediately before bedtime suppresses melatonin, delays the circadian clock, reduces alertness the following morning, and disrupts the circadian timing of sleep. These findings have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. They also have implications for the design of lighting in the built environment and the development of new technologies that minimize the disruptive effects of light on sleep and circadian rhythms.

The Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) is marked by a ∼1.2 °C global cooling that abruptly ended the last glacial period and is coincident with a cosmic dust layer. The origin of this cooling has been attributed to the injection of sulfate aerosols into the stratosphere from one or more bolide impacts. Evidence for these impacts has been controversial, but we report here the discovery of spherules from an impact ∼12.9 ka ago at a YDB site in Pennsylvania. These spherules are 2 to 5 mm in diameter, contain Fe-Ni silicide minerals, and are ∼12.9 ka old. However, the osmium isotopes in the spherules and other YDB samples are inconsistent with a meteoritic contribution, indicating that any extraterrestrial material that may have been deposited at the time is too small to account for the global cooling. Thus, the YDB cooling remains unexplained.

We have previously shown that mice deficient in cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) die young due to severe multiorgan autoimmune disease. To better understand the role of CTLA-4, we ablated CTLA-4 expression in adult mice and compared the resulting autoimmunity with that produced by congenital CTLA-4 deficiency. We found that adult CTLA-4–deficient mice developed spontaneous multiorgan autoimmune disease, which was not fatal. This indicated that CTLA-4 is required for self-tolerance throughout the life span of the mouse. CTLA-4 expression was also important for Treg cell-mediated suppression, but not for Treg cell development. Importantly, the disease phenotype of adult CTLA-4–deficient mice was different from that of congenitally deficient mice, and CTLA-4 expression was required for the development of some, but not all, experimental autoimmune diseases. Thus, the expression of CTLA-4 has major impacts on T cell tolerance and disease.

The origin and diversification of beetles, the most diverse group of animals on Earth, are poorly understood. We used phylogenomics to reconstruct the evolutionary history of beetles, which resolved many long-standing controversies. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling beetles to digest plant cell walls, which are a major component of plant tissues. Our analyses suggest that the origin of beetles coincided with the appearance of flowering plants, and that two major beetle lineages that feed on plants evolved from nonplant-feeding ancestors in the Mesozoic Era, coincident with the first appearances of plant-cell-wall-degrading enzymes encoded in their genomes. These findings suggest that horizontal transfer of these enzymes from bacteria and fungi enabled the evolution of specialized plant feeding, resulting in the remarkable beetle diversity we see today. Thus, beetle diversity resulted from a complex history of low extinction rates, diversification with plants, and novel enzymes.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has become a major obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to redesign the complementarity-determining regions (CDRs) of an antibody to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Through iterative optimization of the CDR regions and experimental measurements, we enable expanded antibody breadth and improved potency against SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can also be applied to other antibodies to achieve broader and more potent neutralization against future emerging variants.

The role of population size in cumulative cultural evolution is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the cumulative evolution of paper-plane technology using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We conclude that larger populations do not enhance artifact performance via cumulative cultural evolution, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance cumulative cultural evolution.

Apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype is the strongest known genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Here we report that APOE alleles control the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major central nervous system cell type that produces APOE and is highly phagocytic. The APOE2 allele enhances the rate of phagocytosis and pruning, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in controlling the rate of accumulation of C1q protein in hippocampus. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth’s inner core is made of iron that crystallized from the liquid state. However, it is difficult to reconcile the present core conditions with the known phase diagram of iron. Recent studies found that it requires an unrealistic degree of undercooling to nucleate the stable phase of iron. This contradiction is referred to as the inner core nucleation paradox. We demonstrated that the metastable phase of iron has a much higher nucleation rate than does the stable phase under core conditions. Thus, the metastable phase nucleation is likely to be the first step of inner core formation, instead of nucleation of the stable phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used recreational drug in the United States. Chronic marijuana use is associated with negative effects on cognition and mood. The present study shows that chronic marijuana abusers have blunted brain reward responses to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). The normal MP-induced increases in DA in the striatum were associated with decreases in DA receptor availability, as measured with PET and [11C]raclopride. In the marijuana abusers, these normal reductions in DA receptor availability were absent. The marijuana abusers also had higher scores for negative emotionality (stress and irritability) and addiction severity. These findings are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation in the marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings have implications for the current move to legalize marijuana.

Language is a quintessentially human ability. Research has long probed the functional architecture of language in the mind and brain using diverse neuroimaging, behavioral, and computational modeling approaches. However, adequate neurally-mechanistic accounts of how meaning might be extracted from language are sorely lacking. Here, we report a first step toward addressing this gap by connecting recent artificial neural networks from machine learning to human recordings during language processing. We find that the most powerful models predict neural and behavioral responses across different datasets up to noise levels. Models that perform better at predicting the next word in a sequence also better predict brain measurements—providing computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the brain. This work thus points toward a more integrative approach to language in the mind and brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success and is now entering scientific computing with full force. However, current DL methods typically suffer from instability, even when universal approximation properties guarantee the existence of stable neural networks (NNs). We address this paradox by demonstrating basic well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of NNs with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. These results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We begin this theory by establishing sufficient conditions for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs in inverse problems. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in a classic psychological experiment published in 1977. It found that people fail to understand exponential growth, which may have contributed to the emergence of the pandemic. We show that the experiment’s results are based on a methodological fallacy, which renders them invalid. This is a cautionary tale for the social sciences. On the one hand, it demonstrates how a methodological fallacy can creep into a study without anyone noticing. On the other hand, it shows that, despite this fallacy, the study’s conclusion may still be correct. Thus, this is a warning against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research. This applies all the more as this study has become a key reference in the debate about the COVID-19 pandemic.

Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, is a chronic granulomatous disease that affects the skin and peripheral nervous system. Diffuse lepromatosis, caused by an uncultured Mycobacterium, shares many clinical features with leprosy. Here, we describe the genome of Mycobacterium lepromatosis and compare it with that of M. leprae. The two genomes are highly similar in size and gene content, and both have undergone extensive reductive evolution. Phylogenetic analyses indicate that M. leprae is a sister group of M. lepromatosis, and the two diverged from their most recent common ancestor approximately 13.9 Mya. A phylogeographic survey by differential PCR revealed that M. leprae is the predominant leprosy-causing Mycobacterium in the Americas, Europe, and Asia, whereas M. lepromatosis is restricted to Mexico. Thus, two distinct Mycobacteria cause similar pathologies in different geographic regions.

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. Recently, the study of quantum quenches revealed that these concepts are intricately intertwined: although the unitary time evolution ensuing from a pure state maintains the system at zero entropy, local properties at long times are captured by a statistical ensemble with nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the entanglement accumulated during the dynamics. We show that the standard quasiparticle picture of the entanglement evolution, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We thoroughly check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

We describe COVI-VAC, the only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development. We show that a single intranasal dose of COVI-VAC provides robust protection against SARS-CoV-2 challenge in Syrian golden hamsters, a relevant in vivo model. COVI-VAC is derived from the ancestral SARS-CoV-2 virus by the introduction of 283 synonymous point mutations that reduce its growth temperature sensitivity. The furin cleavage site in the spike protein was deleted for added safety. The clinical candidate COVI-VAC is highly attenuated yet grows robustly at its permissive temperature. The data presented support the continued development of COVI-VAC as a safe and efficacious vaccine candidate against COVID-19.

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, has had a major impact on human populations throughout history. During the Second Pandemic (14th to 19th centuries), plague caused high mortality in Europe, including the Black Death (1346–1353), but the mechanisms behind the spread of the disease are not fully understood. Many studies suggest that human ectoparasites, such as body lice or human fleas, were responsible for the rapidly developing epidemics, but there is little supporting evidence. Here, we develop a mathematical model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites and show that it fits mortality data from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or respiratory transmission. This supports the hypothesis that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic.

The evolution of brain neuron numbers is a crucial factor in understanding the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. This study directly analyzes neuron numbers across amniotes to reconstruct the evolution of brain neurons. We show that the most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, two groups known for their cognitive prowess. These findings have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

These findings have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition

The mitochondrial chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, current TRAP1 inhibitors are not specific, and some cancers express less TRAP1 than do their normal tissue counterparts, suggesting that TRAP1 function in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are assembled into complex networks in cells. However, how the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin severing mechanism adapts to the filament network context is unknown. We use microfluidics, single-molecule, and single-filament techniques to monitor and quantify ADF/cofilin’s action on isolated filaments and filament networks. We discover that ADF/cofilin binding and severing are strongly influenced by filament mechanical state. In particular, we demonstrate that ADF/cofilin binding induces a mechanical torque on filaments, which dramatically enhances severing. As a consequence, interconnected filament networks are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s severing ability in the complex and highly connected actin network of cells. These results have important implications for our understanding of ADF/cofilin’s role in cells, and for the modeling of actin networks.

Fructose compared with glucose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite. Here we sought to determine the effects of fructose versus glucose on brain, hormone, and appetitive responses to food cues and food-approach behavior. We show that the ingestion of fructose compared with glucose resulted in smaller increases in plasma insulin levels and greater brain responses to food cues in the visual cortex and left orbital frontal cortex. Ingestion of fructose versus glucose also led to greater hunger and desire for food and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose activates brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior.

Madagascar is one of the most isolated islands on Earth, but its population shows a mixture of genetic traits from Africa and Asia. We used a grid-based sampling approach to investigate the recent history of the Malagasy population. We found that the genetic diversity is structured geographically, showing that the island was colonized by two distinct migrant groups from Africa and Asia, which is in contradiction with the hypothesis of a single, already admixed founding population. We also found that the island was colonized by a large number of individuals, both male and female, and that the admixture happened recently, suggesting a rapid colonization that occurred less than 1,000 y ago. This study also shows the power of a grid-based sampling approach for studying recent history.

We demonstrate experimentally that emotional contagion occurs without direct interaction between people. Reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed changed emotional states of people, as measured by their own posts. When people saw less emotional content, they produced less emotional content. These results indicate that emotional contagion occurs without direct interaction between people, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work suggests that social media platforms can influence the emotional states of their users, and that reducing the amount of emotional content on social media platforms might be a useful tool for improving the emotional well-being of users.

The incorporation of modified nucleotides into messenger RNAs (mRNAs) impacts mRNA stability and translation. We show that pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA coding regions can affect translation in two ways. First, replacing a single uridine nucleotide with Ψ in an mRNA codon impedes amino acid addition and EF-Tu GTPase activation. Second, the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for mRNA therapeutics and vaccines that use modified mRNA.

The sense that life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to well-being and may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. In this large population sample of men and women aged 50 and older, higher ratings of the meaningfulness of life were associated with stronger personal relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, greater prosperity, better mental and physical health, less disability, more favorable biomarker profiles, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. Longitudinally over a 4-y period, higher worthwhile ratings predicted positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These associations were not explained by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms.

Four distinct lineages of mammals have independently evolved fully aquatic lifestyles. These aquatic mammals are, on average, much larger than their closest land-dwelling relatives. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and paleontological data to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. We propose that differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms drive this size attractor. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most frequent cause of the common cold, as well as one of the most important causes of asthma exacerbations. Most rhinovirus strains replicate better at the cooler temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at lung temperature, but the underlying mechanisms are not known. Using a mouse-adapted rhinovirus, we found that airway epithelial cells supporting rhinovirus replication initiate a more robust antiviral defense response through RIG-I–like receptor (RLR) signaling at lung temperature relative to nasal cavity temperature. Airway cells with genetic deficiencies in RLR or type I IFN receptor signaling supported much higher levels of viral replication at 37 °C. Thus, cooler temperatures can enable replication of the common cold virus, at least in part, by diminishing antiviral immune responses. These findings may have implications for understanding and treating rhinovirus infections in the airways.

The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of hospital-associated infections, and the third most common cause of death in cystic fibrosis patients. It is known that P. aeruginosa adapts its gene expression and pathogenicity to the surface it encounters. Here we show that one of its major surface adhesins, type IV pili, not only facilitates surface attachment, but also directly activates a chemosensory system that regulates pathogenicity. This mechanism is likely to be important for P. aeruginosa’s ability to colonize a broad range of surfaces, from the skin to the lungs and other mucosal surfaces, and to adapt its pathogenicity to its environment. These findings have implications for the design of therapeutic strategies to combat P. aeruginosa infections.

Agricultural pesticides are applied in high quantities worldwide, and their use is increasing. We provide a comprehensive global metaanalysis of insecticide contamination of surface waters, which is the most important habitat for aquatic life. We show that 52.4% of measured insecticide concentrations exceed legally accepted regulatory threshold levels. This indicates that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. The analysis also shows that the most toxic insecticide group (i.e., pyrethroids) is responsible for a high percentage of these exceedances. These results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices. We also show that there is a lack of scientific monitoring data for ∼90% of global cropland. Thus, our knowledge about insecticide surface water contamination is far from complete.

The current severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic will not end if the virus continuously spills back into susceptible animal reservoirs. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a widely distributed cervid in North, Central, and South America. We sequenced the entire genomes of 94 deer samples and identified 12 lineages. The geographic distribution and nesting of clusters of deer and human lineages strongly suggest multiple human-to-deer transmission events followed by subsequent deer-to-deer spread. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. Our findings highlight an urgent need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

Hydropower has been the leading source of renewable energy across the world, accounting for up to 71% of this supply as of 2016. This capacity was built up in North America and Europe between 1920 and 1970 when thousands of dams were built. The same problems are being repeated: disrupting river ecology, deforestation, losing aquatic and terrestrial biodiversity, releasing substantial greenhouse gases, displacing thousands of people, and altering people’s livelihoods plus affecting the food systems, water quality, and agriculture near them. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia, and the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and tau tangles are pathological hallmarks of this neurodegenerative disorder. Microglia are known to be activated in AD, and it is generally accepted that this chronic inflammation is driven by the presence of Aβ plaques and neuronal cell death. However, we demonstrate here that microglia are already activated in a transgenic rat model of AD before the formation of plaques or neuronal death. The source of this early inflammation is the accumulation of Aβ within neurons, which triggers a unique inflammatory profile. These results have important implications for AD, since they suggest that Aβ-induced neuronal death and inflammation may be a vicious cycle, with each contributing to the other in a self-perpetuating loop. Thus, therapies that target Aβ or neuroinflammation may be most effective when administered early in the course of AD.

The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes is still unresolved. We base our claim that the Southern Levant is the place where economic exploitation of chickens was first practiced on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The number of proteins that fold through distinct native-like intermediates and pathways is growing rapidly, but the principles that govern this behavior are still unclear. Here we have studied the folding of the large two-domain maltose binding protein (370 residues) by an advanced hydrogen-exchange mass-spectrometry method and other techniques. The results show that folding occurs through a distinct helix plus sheet folding intermediate that is composed of segments that are distant in the primary structure but adjacent in the native protein where they form the longest residue-to-residue contact. The intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway, and folding to the native state occurs in more than one step, the first of which forms structure adjacent to the intermediate. These results add MBP to the growing list of proteins that fold this way.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are often described as alarmones because their cellular concentration increases in response to stress. Recently, they have been shown to function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. Removal of this cap is critical for initiating 5′ end-dependent degradation of those RNAs. The predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts in such conditions. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. This unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4 caps and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress.

Severe sepsis is associated with a persistent immunosuppression that increases the risk of secondary infections and mortality. We demonstrated that citrulline administration restores T cell function and proliferation while reducing the expansion of regulatory T cells and myeloid-derived suppressor cells during sepsis. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Furthermore, our data shed new light on the role of arginine/citrulline metabolism in the control of T cell function and its potential application in clinical settings. Finally, our study demonstrates the importance of mitochondrial function in T cell activation and its modulation in sepsis.

We assemble a census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, providing a quantitative description of the composition of the biosphere. We highlight the uneven geographical distribution of the kingdoms of life: plants dominate the land biosphere, animals the marine realm, and bacteria and archaea the deep subsurface. We revise the estimates of marine biomass, providing a twofold increase of the previous values. We describe the structure of the global marine biomass pyramid, which exhibits more consumers than producers, a property known as inverse pyramid. We quantify the impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. This work provides a quantitative description of the global biosphere, offering a baseline for future studies on the dynamics of the biomass of the kingdoms of life.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a remarkable phenomenon in which a system, starting from an arbitrary initial state, evolves to a state of criticality, where it exhibits power-law statistics. SOC was discovered in discrete models, and it is not clear whether it can exist in continuous models. We present a continuous tropical model that exhibits SOC. This model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the archetypical discrete SOC model. Our model is related to several phenomena in biology and chemistry. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation. We hope that our discovery will stimulate further interdisciplinary research.

Diamond is a wide-bandgap material with unique optical, electronic, and chemical properties. It is the hardest material and has high thermal conductivity. It is also biocompatible and stable under extreme conditions. These properties have enabled numerous applications in various fields, ranging from jewelry to electronics to space exploration. Here, we show that diamond can be made fully metallic under mechanical strain. This is counterintuitive, as diamond is a wide-bandgap material. We also show that the bandgap can be made fully tunable. These findings offer opportunities for strain engineering of diamond for a wide range of applications. Our findings are also significant for fundamental studies of the relationship between mechanical deformation and electronic/photonic properties of materials. Our findings can be extended to other materials.

The root nodule-specific cysteine-rich (NCR) peptides are a large family of cationic, cysteine-rich, and mostly antimicrobial peptides that are highly abundant in Medicago truncatula nodules. They are thought to be involved in the legume–rhizobial mutualistic symbiosis. Here, we show that NCR044 is a potent fungicide. It targets multiple stages of the fungal life cycle, including the production of reactive oxygen species, binding to the cell wall, leakage of intracellular content, and disruption of the nucleus. The mode of action of NCR044 is unlike that of any other known antifungal compounds. As a spray-on application, NCR044 significantly controlled gray mold disease. The results suggest that NCR peptides can be developed as a new class of broad-spectrum antifungal compounds to control plant fungal diseases. This will help to reduce the use of toxic and environmentally hazardous synthetic fungicides.

The sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract, suggesting that the female contributes to sperm function. Female-derived proteins associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the sperm proteome after 4 d of storage. Female contributions to sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that the female may support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. These findings have implications for understanding the biology of sperm storage and longevity as well as the evolution of male–female interactions.

We have determined the effects of force on the binding of the von Willebrand factor A1 domain (VWA1) to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) of platelets, which is the first step in the interaction of von Willebrand factor (VWF) with GPIbα during blood clotting. We have found that force can induce VWF to switch to a conformation with faster on-rate for binding to GPIbα. The on-rate for binding of VWF to GPIbα is greatly increased by force, and the off-rate is decreased, providing a mechanism for how force can activate the binding of VWF to GPIbα. Mutations that disrupt binding of VWF to GPIbα are greatly exacerbated by force, explaining how mutations can cause the common bleeding disorder von Willebrand disease. These results are also consistent with the bulk phase measurements. Thus, we have correlated single molecule measurements with bulk phase measurements.

The human microbiome consists of communities of microbes, including bacteria, archaea, viruses, and eukaryotes, which colonize the body. The composition of the microbiome is associated with numerous human diseases, and holds promise as a diagnostic or therapeutic target. While much is known about the bacterial and archaeal components of the microbiome, much less is known about the viral component, despite the fact that viruses greatly outnumber bacteria in the microbiome. This study analyzes thousands of datasets to assemble a comprehensive catalog of viruses associated with the human body, and to determine which of these viruses are associated with human disease. Hundreds of new virus taxa are discovered, and over 2,200 strong virus–disease associations are found. These results have implications for future microbiome-based diagnostics and therapies.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the largest sources of uncertainty in climate prediction. To improve climate models, it is essential to obtain high-resolution simultaneous observations of diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties. The dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) provides a solution to this challenge. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI processes. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The dual-FOV HSRL has the potential to become a significant contributor to ACI investigations. The results from this study will help to reduce the uncertainty in climate predictions. This technique can be used in many other locations around the world.

The temperature of Earth's surface environment is a fundamental parameter in both physical and biological geosciences. Although paleotemperatures may be inferred from the isotopic compositions of marine cherts, uncertainties regarding the isotopic record have led to skepticism regarding the validity of previous interpretations. We here present an independent method for assessing the validity of previously inferred paleotemperatures based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. Our results are consistent with a cooling of Earth's surface temperature over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, supporting the validity of previous interpretations of isotopic data. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history.

The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is the most slowly activating and deactivating K+ channel. It is normally insensitive to C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can be induced to inactivate in a C-type fashion. The extent and rate of BK channel C-type inactivation inversely correlate with channel-open probability. This correlation suggests that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This is supported by the observation that the BK channel’s normal closing can be induced by hyperpolarized membrane potentials or decreased intracellular calcium, conditions that favor C-type inactivation. Thus, the BK channel’s activation gate may coexist with or be spatially overlapped by the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. This study has implications for the mechanism of C-type inactivation.

The malaria parasite enters the human red blood cell (RBC) via surface receptors on the parasite binding to receptors on the red cell surface. Despite this binding interaction being critical for entry, its function is unknown. Here, using a combination of physical techniques to define the biophysical properties of the erythrocyte, we show that the malaria parasite primes the red cell surface, altering its biophysical nature and facilitating entry. This finding constitutes a major change in our concept of malaria parasite entry, suggesting that it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This study opens up a whole new area of research into the biophysical nature of the malaria parasite and its host cell.

Diamond is known to be an excellent material for a wide range of applications from electronics to quantum technologies to jewelry. Recently, ultralarge elastic deformation of diamond under nanoindentation was experimentally discovered. This enables us to explore new functionalities of diamond by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, so that its electronic bandgap fully vanishes. We identify the strain pathway to metallization and the conditions for phonon instability and phase transition to graphite. This work offers opportunities to explore new functionalities of diamond and to develop a new field of diamond strain engineering. It also demonstrates a paradigm of machine-learning–assisted discovery science in condensed matter.

Influenza virus causes seasonal outbreaks in temperate regions, with increased incidence of disease during the dry winter months. Here, we show that exposure of mice to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair, leading to more severe disease upon influenza virus infection. We also show that dry air exposure renders mice more susceptible to caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results indicate that inhalation of dry air compromises host defense against influenza virus infection and worsens disease outcome. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the seasonal nature of influenza virus outbreaks. Interventions that improve indoor humidity during the winter months may be considered as a public health measure to mitigate influenza virus outbreaks.

The human brain is a massively parallel system. It is therefore well suited to process streams of information, such as the stream of words that makes up a sentence. But how does the brain merge words into phrases and phrases into a sentence? Here, we provide initial intracranial evidence for a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This compression of the language stream into a tree structure is associated with a sudden increase in brain activity in a broad set of language-related areas, comprising multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal sites. Our results are consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in animals, which plays important roles in development and disease. The pathway requires two essential scaffolds, Axin1 or Axin2 (the two genes are highly similar and redundant). We show here that the two genes are co-regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic levels, but the regulation is differential, leading to differential responsiveness of the two proteins that can be used for tissue-specific control. This kind of subtle differential regulation underlies the functional redundancy of similar genes that is commonly found in vertebrates. The finding also has implications for disease, since aberrant Wnt signaling is found in many cancers, and the differential regulation may be exploited for cancer therapy.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a critical site for the control of feeding behavior. Electrical stimulation of the LH induces feeding behavior, and this effect has been attributed to the activation of GABA neurons that inhibit dopaminergic neurons, causing them to release dopamine, which then drives feeding. Here, we show that while the LH does drive feeding, the mechanism does not involve the dopamine system. Rather, the LH drives feeding by activating GABA neurons in the vicinity of the locus coeruleus. These findings have implications for understanding obesity, as the LH is a target for deep brain stimulation to treat obesity, and the role of dopamine in the control of feeding has been a major focus. Thus, the dopamine system is not involved in the control of feeding by the LH, and the mechanism of action of deep brain stimulation for obesity may be different than proposed.

Symbiotic dinitrogen (N2)-fixing bacteria are a valuable resource for sustainable agriculture, as they provide fixed N to their plant hosts. We have developed a synthetic N2-fixing symbiosis, in which the expression of the master regulator of N2-fixing genes in the bacterium is controlled by a plant. Our synthetic symbiosis is specific, as the bacterium is unable to express the N2-fixing genes in nontarget plants. Our work is a major step toward engineering N2-fixing symbioses in cereals, which could sustainably supply fixed N for agriculture. Our approach could also be used to control other symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria in plants and animals. This would allow the design of new symbioses and the fine control of existing ones, with the aim of developing sustainable agriculture and medicine.

Deforestation in the Amazon is driven by a complex set of economic, political, and social factors. In this paper, we evaluate the impact of a community-based monitoring program that combines remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that this type of community monitoring may reduce deforestation in indigenous territories in the Peruvian Amazon. This is important because indigenous territories are a critical part of the Amazon forest and are under threat from increasing deforestation. Our results also suggest that community monitoring may be most effective in communities that face the greatest threats. These results have implications for sustainable forest management in the Amazon and beyond.

The auditory organs of all animals are constrained by the animals’ body sizes. Here, we show that hearing in the spider is not constrained by the body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured web. The spider web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements approaching the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors.

Fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality rate attributable to outdoor air pollution, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. Removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C warming, and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, which can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The model simulations and analysis presented here are unique in their scope and extent, and provide a comprehensive assessment of the climate and public health outcomes attributable to fossil fuel use.

The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic has led to the development of numerous vaccines, with more in the pipeline. Here, we describe an engineered receptor-binding domain (RBD) variant that is more immunogenic than the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines, has improved binding to ACE2, and exhibits heterotypic binding to two recently reported variants of concern. We show that a nanoparticle made from this engineered RBD protects mice from weight loss when challenged with SARS-CoV-2. Our results suggest that this engineered RBD could be used in vaccines to improve their performance and global accessibility via low-cost microbial manufacturing. Such an approach may be useful for rapidly responding to future epidemics and pandemics.

We have identified ligands for the human receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK) and shown that these ligands are conserved in zebrafish. We have further shown that the zebrafish ligands are capable of activating the zebrafish receptor and the human ALK in cell-based assays. Finally, we have used the zebrafish system to show that the ligand–receptor pairs are required for development of neural crest-derived pigment cells in zebrafish embryos and adult fish. This work has implications for our understanding of human neuroblastoma and pigment cell development. Our results also provide an example of a vertebrate system that can be used to identify and study novel receptor tyrosine kinase ligands.

Yersinia pestis, the bacterium responsible for plague, has caused numerous devastating outbreaks throughout human history and is still endemic in certain parts of the world. The historical record of the bacterium is largely based on modern-day genomic data, with only a few Y. pestis genomes recovered from the medieval and post-medieval periods. Here, we present 17 ancient Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age, greatly increasing the number of genomes available from this pivotal period in the bacterium’s history. This allowed us to explore the diversity of Y. pestis during its early evolution and to track its geographic spread across continents. This work provides new insights into the ecology and evolution of plague in its formative years.

This work examines men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity (HM)—the culturally idealized form of masculinity—to understand support for Donald Trump among men and women. Across seven studies (n = 2,007), we find that HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. This was true when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. Whereas HM predicted evaluations of Trump, social and prejudiced attitudes predicted evaluations of his democratic challengers: Clinton in 2016 and Biden in 2020. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.

Grassland-derived Mollisols are the most extensive and productive cropland soils on the planet. Yet, the fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) under intensive cropping is poorly understood, particularly the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated organic matter. We assessed the impact of soil health management practices on SOC accrual and distribution and their relationship to soil microbial traits in a 29-y-old field study in the North Central United States and then assessed results from published studies worldwide. We found that diverse, rotationally grazed pastures increased SOC accrual and distribution toward more stable forms of SOC. Other soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage and diversified crop rotations with cover crops and manure, increased SOC in the short term but did not lead to significant accrual of stable SOC. These findings highlight the key role of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic highlights the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viruses. We developed a risk ranking framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. The risk ranking is based on the best available scientific evidence of factors that contribute to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We used the framework to rank the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses, including many newly discovered viruses. The publicly accessible SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a key reward that plants offer to pollinators. Here, we show that the red nectar of the rare Malagasy plant Nesocodon mauritianus is caused by a previously unknown alkaloid. We show that the production of this alkaloid is the result of a convergent evolutionary process in a distantly related plant family that also produces red nectar. We demonstrate that the alkaloid is attractive to geckos, the most likely pollinators of Nesocodon, and that the production of the alkaloid is catalyzed by three enzymes secreted into the nectar. Our work shows how plants can use a limited number of compounds in a convergent manner to produce visually attractive nectars to promote pollination. This is particularly relevant in light of the ongoing global pollinator crisis.

We generated the first population-level genome data from the Early Medieval period in Europe, which revealed a complex pattern of ancestry in a group of 41 individuals dating mostly to the 5th/6th century AD from present-day Bavaria in southern Germany. While most men had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, many women exhibited a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of women with artificial skull deformations suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The continuing Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) outbreak highlights the threat of bat coronaviruses to global health. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry mechanism of bat coronavirus HKU4. Similar to MERS-CoV, HKU4 uses dipeptidyl peptidase 4 as its receptor, but has a preference for bat cells over human cells for receptor-mediated entry. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human dipeptidyl peptidase 4 and human cellular proteases for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions.
