Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) of febrile patients in Cambodia revealed a diverse pathogen landscape, including vector-borne, zoonotic, and other emerging pathogens. This study demonstrates the utility of pathogen-agnostic mNGS surveillance to identify the breadth of circulating pathogens in resource-scarce settings and to inform public health response. We show that mNGS is more sensitive than routine diagnostic testing for detection of vector-borne and zoonotic pathogens. We also demonstrate the feasibility of using the global cloud-based platform, CZID (“IDseq”), for mNGS pathogen surveillance in low-resource settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can help identify emerging pathogens and allow for rapid public health response. This study has implications for global pathogen surveillance and response to emerging epidemics.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template. In eukaryotes, pol δ requires the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp to function. The stability of the pol δ·PCNA complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. Our results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating undamaged DNA, which promotes rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Such behavior has profound implications on lagging strand synthesis in humans. We anticipate that the unique kinetic assays that we developed will be used to analyze the stability of other protein complexes that are involved in DNA replication and repair. These assays will also be instrumental in analyzing the stability of pol δ in other species.

Darwinian life requires the ability to replicate genetic information and to convert it into functional molecules. Although all extant life relies on proteins for these tasks, life in the ancestral RNA world would have used only RNA enzymes. Here, we describe the in vitro evolution of an improved RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize complex structured RNAs, including functional aptamers and ribozymes, and replicate short RNA sequences in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. These results pave the way toward the in vitro evolution of self-sustained RNA-based life forms.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 may lead to a severe hyperinflammatory syndrome, in which T lymphocytes and mononuclear macrophages play important roles. Tocilizumab, a recombinant humanized anti-human interleukin 6 receptor monoclonal antibody, has been used in clinic for many years in treating rheumatoid arthritis and other inflammatory diseases. It has been approved by the ethics committee to be used in severe and critical COVID-19 patients in Anhui province, China. This report is about the experience in the first 20 cases. Within 5 d after giving tocilizumab, 75.0% of the patients needed less oxygen therapy, and 90.5% of patients showed decreased lung lesion opacity in CT scan. No obvious adverse reactions were observed. All patients have been discharged on average 15.1 d after giving tocilizumab. This is a promising treatment for severe COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for fungi; however, the mechanisms of copper homeostasis in fungi are not well understood. We report here that the secondary metabolites xanthocillins produced by Aspergillus fumigatus bind copper and impact cellular copper content. The xanthocillins are produced as isocyanides and have copper-dependent antimicrobial properties, including inhibition of laccase activity. The xanthocillins are produced by several filamentous fungi, suggesting that eukaryotic natural products have an unknown role in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. The discovery of copper-binding xanthocillins expands our understanding of the role of secondary metabolites in fungal metal homeostasis and interactions with other microbes. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fungal-derived xanthocillins in the environment and in the context of human health.

Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is stable at low pressures. Its detection in a mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, implies that the mudstone formed at temperatures >870 °C, which is unlikely. We conclude that the tridymite is detrital, sourced from silicic volcanism possibly related to the formation of Gale crater. The other mudstone crystalline minerals (feldspar, cristobalite, and magnetite) also likely are detrital, sourced from the crater wall/rim/central peak. Amorphous material in the mudstone is a mixture of high-SiO2 glass/opal-A, opal-CT, and mixed-cation salts and oxides. The latter are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple infiltrations of variable aqueous solutions, whereas the high-SiO2 glass/opal-A likely is a residue of acid leaching and/or glass diagenesis. Anhydrite is a late-stage fracture/vein fill. This mudstone is a cogenetic mixture of detrital and authigenic material.

Late-spring frosts (LSFs) affect the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones, but despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We combine observations of LSFs with trait data on more than 1,500 woody species to forecast forest vulnerability to spring frosts under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. We show that in Europe and Asia, where LSFs are becoming more common, forests are dominated by tree species that are vulnerable to spring frosts. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are implicated in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, Th17 cells exhibit developmental plasticity, giving rise to a Th1-like subset that expresses IFN-γ but not IL-17. We found that Th17 cells induced colitis in a mouse model by transitioning to Th1-like cells and by promoting the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These findings have implications for the treatment of IBD, as current therapies target the Th1 pathway but not Th17 cells. Our results suggest that therapies that target the Th17 pathway may be beneficial in certain forms of IBD. Furthermore, as Th17 cells are implicated in other autoimmune diseases, these findings may have broader implications for the treatment of autoimmune disease in general.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with motor neuron loss. We report a rapid, highly reproducible method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into astrocytes (i-astrocytes). We show non-cell autonomous toxicity to motor neurons is found following coculture of i-astrocytes from both familial ALS patients with mutations in superoxide dismutase or hexanucleotide expansion in C9orf72 (the two most frequent causes of ALS) and sporadic ALS patients. Easy production and expansion of i-astrocytes now enables rapid ALS disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This approach can be applied to other neurodegenerative diseases for which there are no cures. The i-astrocytes are available to other investigators upon request.

The capacity of pathogens to infect their vectors is a major determinant of the transmission of disease. We now demonstrate that the agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, encodes an anti-antibacterial protein that alters the gut microbiota of its vector, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick and be transmitted to humans. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. These data are significant because they provide insight into the molecular mechanisms by which pathogens influence vectors to enhance colonization. This is a critical first step in the transmission of disease. This work also provides insight into the evolution of pathogen–vector interactions.

We describe a new species, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China that is a member of the Pygostylia, the short-tailed sister group of all living birds. This discovery is important for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan, which is characterized by a number of novelties including a fused scapulocoracoid (shoulder girdle). The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in basal birds is a major puzzle because it represents a major reversal to the nonavian theropod condition. Here, we provide a phylogenetic analysis and discuss the significance of this taxon for understanding mosaic evolution and adaptation to dense forest habitats in early birds. Jinguofortis also shows that reduction in manual digits (fingers) of birds occurred very early in the evolution of the modern avian bauplan.

We show observational evidence for a stratospheric water vapor feedback—a warmer climate increases stratospheric water vapor, and because stratospheric water vapor is itself a greenhouse gas, this leads to further warming. An estimate of its magnitude from a climate model yields a value of +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), suggesting that this feedback plays an important role in our climate system. This is particularly true given that it acts in addition to the tropospheric water vapor feedback, which acts only in the troposphere. This work highlights the importance of the stratosphere in our climate system, a system that we are in the process of changing in ways that are not completely understood.

We show that frogs have evolved green coloration multiple times during their evolutionary history by increasing the concentration of biliverdin in their blood and tissues. We also identified the protein responsible for this phenomenon: a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This serpin, named biliverdin-binding serpin (BBS), binds biliverdin with high affinity, and its concentration in the tissues controls the color of the animals, providing the physiological basis for crypsis in green foliage even under near-infrared light. This study presents molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describes a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduces a function for a member of the serpin superfamily.

Pluripotency factors such as NANOG are important for the maintenance of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for the initiation and recurrence of breast cancer and for drug resistance and metastasis. We report here that exposure of breast cancer cells to hypoxia led to increased expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which demethylated NANOG mRNA, resulting in increased NANOG expression and the CSC phenotype. These changes were mediated by hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs), HIF-1α and HIF-2α. ALKBH5 expression was also increased in primary breast tumors in association with increased NANOG expression and with HIF-1α or HIF-2α expression. Thus, HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression mediates enrichment of CSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Inhibitors of ALKBH5 activity may, therefore, be a useful adjuvant to radiotherapy for breast cancer patients.

The production of pocket-size Bibles in the 13th century is a milestone in the history of the book. The use of ultrafine parchment for these manuscripts has been the subject of much debate, with the term “uterine vellum” used to describe the material. This has led some to suggest that the skins of aborted or newborn animals were used. We show that this material can be analyzed without damage to the manuscript using a modified version of ZooMS (zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry), which allows the species of each folio to be identified. We find that the material is made from the skins of several species of mature animals, which is consistent with the availability of hides in the 13th century. We find no evidence for the use of unusual animals, such as rabbits or humans.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe biotic crisis in the last 542 My. The cause of this extinction, and the controls on its dynamics, are enigmatic, in part, because of a lack of a high-precision age model. U-Pb zircon dates for five volcanic ash beds from the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China, define an age model that reveals that the extinction occurred over a surprisingly short interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major perturbation in the carbon cycle immediately precedes the extinction, suggesting that carbon cycle disruption was the dominant control on extinction dynamics. These data also allow an evaluation of the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms proposed to explain the extinction.

Chronic inflammation, such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), is a major cause of morbidity worldwide. We demonstrate that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in controlling intestinal inflammation by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Mechanistically, RORα corepresses NF-κB target genes by recruiting histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) to specific promoters. These results suggest that RORα-mediated epigenetic regulation of NF-κB target genes is a potential therapeutic target for chronic inflammation diseases.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus is constantly mutating. Some of these mutations occur in the virus spike, which is the viral protein that binds to the ACE2 receptor on human cells and is a major target of the immune system. Here, we compare the D614 and G614 versions of the spike protein, which differ only at a single amino acid residue. We show that the G614 mutant spike adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to ACE2 and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. Since most currently circulating viruses have the G614 mutation, our results suggest that the virus may be better adapted to human transmission compared to the ancestral virus that was transmitted to humans from an animal host.

In this model, players choose actions in each period, and the payoffs depend on the history of play. A natural restriction is to consider only histories that occur with positive probability (i.e., those in the tail of the distribution of histories). The COVID-19 pandemic is having a devastating impact on the United States, with more than 215,000 deaths as of mid-October 2020. The disease is disproportionately affecting Black and Latino Americans, who are experiencing higher death rates than Whites. We estimate that COVID-19 will reduce US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, to 77.48 y, which would be the lowest since 2003. We also estimate that life expectancy at age 65 y will fall by 0.87 y. COVID-19 is estimated to increase the Black−White life expectancy gap from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating the progress made in reducing this gap since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (known as the Latino paradox), would see their advantage over Whites fall from over 3 y to less than 1 y.

We calculate the fundamental chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, as a function of pressure, and we show their close relation to the main chemical phenomena under pressure. We predict the pressure-induced chemical behavior of elements and explain anomalies in the behavior of elements under pressure. We provide a chemical interpretation of the pressure-induced metallization process. We explain the formation of compounds under pressure and the pressure-induced changes in compounds. We explain the pressure-induced formation of new crystal structures, including the famous perovskite structure. Our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales can be used as predictive tools in high-pressure chemistry. Our approach can be extended to other chemical properties. We believe that our work will stimulate a new era in high-pressure chemistry.

Understanding the role of fire in the global carbon cycle is important for projecting future climate. We find that global fire activity has been decreasing since the 1970s, which has led to an increase in the carbon stored in terrestrial ecosystems and has offset warming. We show that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks, as caused by changing fire regimes, are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emissions scenarios. We demonstrate that future reductions in fire emissions may offset 5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. However, regionally, there is a risk of more extreme fires, which would increase emissions and have implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of better understanding the controls on fire activity to reduce uncertainty in future projections.

The mutualism between the bobtail squid, Euprymna scolopes, and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a model system for studying how host and microbial partners adapt to each other over evolutionary time scales. Here, we show that the host provides a key nutrient, chitin, to the symbionts at night, and that the symbionts metabolize the chitin to alter their environment, specifically the pH of the habitat in the host tissue. These results suggest that the host regulates the microbial community in its tissues by providing specific nutrients, which in turn modulate the conditions experienced by the microbes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how host–microbe interactions can become fine-tuned over evolutionary time scales. It also has implications for our understanding of how the microbiota of animals are established and maintained.

We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as sequences of topics. Our method integrates topic modeling and word embedding. We apply our method to narratives about violent deaths in the United States. We identify 225 latent topics, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We also characterize the gender bias of the topics. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. Our code is available at https://github.com/d-m-lewis/discourse_atom_topic_modeling.

The second plague pandemic in medieval Europe is traditionally explained by the establishment of Yersinia pestis reservoirs in Europe, after a first introduction in the Mediterranean harbors in the 14th century. This hypothesis is based on the observation of recurrent epidemics in Europe, without taking into account the climatic context of these events. Our analysis of 7,711 georeferenced plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records shows that climate fluctuations in Asia preceded European epidemics by 15 y, suggesting that the bacterium was reintroduced into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. This study questions the existence of permanent medieval European plague reservoirs, with important implications for our understanding of the disease’s epidemiology.

Sea stars (asteroids) are important components of marine communities worldwide. Recently, sea-star (asteroid) wasting disease (SSWD) has resulted in extensive mortalities of at least 20 species on the Northeast Pacific Coast. Here, we present evidence that SSWD is caused by a newly discovered sea star-associated densovirus (SSaDV). Transmission trials and field surveys indicate that SSaDV is associated with diseased asteroids and that SSaDV load increases as asteroids progress through the disease. SSaDV was also detected in other echinoderms, in plankton, and in sediments, providing a possible mechanism for the rapid spread of the disease throughout the North American Pacific Coast and beyond. Knowledge of the cause of SSWD will allow for better understanding of its spread and impacts on marine communities. SSaDV may also provide a model for study of emerging diseases in echinoderms and other invertebrate taxa.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a hematologic malignancy with poor survival. The interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP; IL1R3) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. Here, we demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.

Madagascar is an island located ∼400 km off the coast of Africa, but its genetic diversity is influenced by both African and Asian populations. We used a grid-based sampling approach to study the genomic diversity of 2,704 individuals from 257 Malagasy villages, showing that the genetic diversity of the island is the result of a recent and rapid admixture between Bantu-speaking Eastern Africans and Austronesian-speaking seafarers. This admixture was geographically and demographically heterogeneous, showing that the island was colonized by two distinct migrant groups, one coming from the east and the other from the south. We also show that the present-day genetic diversity is influenced by geography, independent of the admixture, suggesting that a few centuries are sufficient to generate a detectable structure in a human population. This study provides new insights into the peopling of Madagascar.

We describe a 164-nucleotide RNA that encodes a 28-amino acid protein and modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The encoded protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. Interestingly, the RNA also base pairs with two mRNAs, repressing their expression. The protein-encoding and base-pairing functions compete, suggesting the two functions are not required simultaneously. This is the first report, to our knowledge, of a small RNA that encodes a protein and also base pairs with target mRNAs in Escherichia coli. Thus, the dual-function RNA represents a previously undescribed way to modulate carbon utilization. The observation of dual function is likely to have implications for other sRNAs with “noncoding” regions.

SARS-CoV-2 continues to evolve through emerging variants, which present a major obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to redesign the complementarity-determining regions (CDRs) of a neutralizing antibody to achieve broader and more potent activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Through iterative optimization of the CDR regions and experimental measurements, we enable expanded antibody breadth and improved potency by ∼10- to 600-fold against SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work demonstrates the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules.

Continuous crop monitoring systems are key to detect and manage agricultural production anomalies. Current systems rely on satellite imagery and/or crop growth models. Here, we exploit a legacy source of information: operational crop expert surveys with long and uninterrupted records. Crop expert assessments, despite their subjective and categorical nature, capture the complexities of assessing the “status” of a crop better than any model or remote sensing retrieval. We show that it is possible to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. This variable is statistically robust, stable over time, and valid nation-wide. It can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason.

Language processing involves the ability to store and integrate pieces of information in working memory over short periods of time. According to the dominant view, information is maintained through sustained, elevated neural activity. Other work has argued that short-term synaptic facilitation can serve as a substrate of memory. Here we propose that memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that these adaptive changes in excitability provide memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. On this account, spiking activity writes information into coupled dynamic variables that control adaptation and move at slower timescales than the membrane potential. Information is continuously read back into the active membrane state for processing. This mechanism is suitable for language.

Soil respiration is a major yet poorly understood flux in the global carbon cycle, and its response to climatic warming is hypothesized to have significant implications for future global temperatures. We analyze the largest global dataset of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements to date, totaling >3,800 observations from 27 warming experiments spanning nine biomes. Our analysis reveals a Gaussian response in respiration rates with temperature, increasing up to a threshold of ∼25 °C and decreasing with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. These findings have important implications for climate change mitigation.

The evolution of plastid genomes is influenced by a variety of factors, including the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution under progressively relaxed functional constraints during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. The model is based on analyses of the evolution of the plastid genome of the parasitic plant Epifagus virginiana and its relatives. We show that relaxed purifying selection in all plastid genes is linked to obligate parasitism, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis. This model can be applied to other organelle genomes that have undergone major lifestyle changes.

The Cape Town “Day Zero” drought was caused by a combination of natural variability and anthropogenic climate change. Using a high-resolution climate model, we estimate that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. We further show that anthropogenic climate change is increasing the likelihood of such droughts and that the probability of occurrence will continue to increase in the future, especially under higher emission scenarios. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. These results have implications for water resource management in water-scarce regions around the world. This study demonstrates the importance of using high-resolution models for regional climate change impact studies.

The discovery of a new composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite from the Trinity nuclear test site is reported. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. The formation of quasicrystals in trinitite is shown to be analogous to that in the Khatyrka meteorite and in experiments simulating meteorite impacts, demonstrating that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. The new findings also provide a new window onto the science and history of the Manhattan Project and the development of the atomic age.

The formation of the isocyclic ring of (bacterio)chlorophylls is catalyzed by cyclase enzymes. The reaction is highly unusual, and the chemistry used by the two classes of cyclase is unknown. Here, we show that Ycf54 is an integral component of the O2-dependent cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that there are at least two other classes of cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms, one of which uses a newly discovered protein, BciE, as a subunit. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of the most abundant modified tetrapyrroles on Earth, and the evolution of the cyclase enzyme is discussed. The results also have implications for the biosynthesis of other isocyclic tetrapyrroles, such as heme and siroheme. The cyclase reaction is highly unusual, and its mechanism remains enigmatic. Thus, the elucidation of the chemistry used by these enzymes is a major challenge for future chemical and biochemical studies.

Neuroinflammation is associated with many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Apoptosis signal-related kinase 1 (ASK1) has been shown to be a key mediator of neuroinflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), an animal model of MS. Here, we generated conditional ASK1 knockout mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during EAE. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages induces a proinflammatory environment that activates astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology, which may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the current California drought.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a highly heritable neurodevelopmental disorder with a very complicated etiology, which involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple ASD-risk gene homologs in flies. Mutations of five ASD-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility. Thus, behavioral inflexibility is a common phenotype of ASD-risk genes. This study provides an important advance in the understanding of the shared pathophysiology of ASD.

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine cross-national psychophysiological reactions to real news content. It accordingly offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. This helps account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. It also highlights individual-level variation in reactions to news, however. This suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” By making clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, this work helps account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. By highlighting individual-level variation, however, it suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ release-activated Ca2+ (CRAC) channel is a central regulator of Ca2+ homeostasis and cellular function. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in STIM1 associated with Stormorken syndrome, a rare autosomal-dominant condition characterized by congenital miosis, thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, and tubular myopathy, and in ORAI1 associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions.

The spreading of protein aggregates throughout the nervous system is thought to be an important element of many neurodegenerative diseases. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that huntingtin aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are released from neurons and internalized by other neurons, where they cause non–cell-autonomous toxicity. We show that inhibition of endocytosis in vulnerable neurons prevents their loss and that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1. These studies demonstrate that active release and uptake of huntingtin aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These studies also highlight the utility of Drosophila in dissecting out the mechanisms of neurodegenerative diseases.

The bat immune system is considered an enigma because of its unique characteristics, such as long-term cohabitation with numerous potentially pathogenic microorganisms and a high concentration of immunosuppressants in some tissues. This study identified a potent immunosuppressant, mycophenolate (MTX), which is concentrated in the salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and revealed that MTX targets the leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) enzyme to inhibit leukotriene A4 (LTA4) hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. The results show that MTX inhibits the antiviral responses of the host and facilitates viral infection and that MTX-LTA4H targeting may be a potential therapeutic strategy. These results provide deeper insight into the immune system of bats and support the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H.

We report a new class of dual serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) 1/2 inhibitors that potently block cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also show that these inhibitors are highly effective against B cell malignancies, particularly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which paradoxically relies on a source of glycine other than amino acid uptake. These inhibitors are highly selective and have an excellent safety profile, making them attractive candidates for further development. This work also provides a unique example of a metabolic vulnerability that can be exploited by pharmacologic inhibition. Finally, we provide evidence that dual SHMT1/2 inhibitors are well tolerated in vivo and are currently being evaluated in a phase I trial.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with a complex and poorly understood pathology. A variety of apparently unrelated genetic mutations predispose to ALS, which is characterized by the death of motor neurons and the formation of intracellular protein inclusions. We show here that the proteins that form these inclusions have one major shared property: They are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other tissues, suggesting that their aggregation is specific to the ALS disease context. These results suggest that ALS-associated inclusions result from a set of metastable proteins that are prone to aggregation when protein homeostasis collapses in motor neurons. This hypothesis provides a general mechanism that can explain how different ALS mutations lead to the formation of distinct inclusion types. It also suggests that the study of supersaturation may provide a powerful tool for the identification of proteins that are prone to aggregation in specific disease contexts.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This paper is significant because it brings together the fields of quantum optics and many-body physics with the goal of creating novel quantum states of matter using neutral atoms.

The very early evolution and diversification of angiosperms is poorly understood, especially the relationship between morphology, ecology, and reproduction. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, an exquisitely preserved, completely aquatic, early Cretaceous angiosperm from Spain. Based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses and opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the very early diversification of angiosperms.

Human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous human pathogen associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. We present 10 genomes of B19V from individuals who lived ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. Our results show that B19V has been associated with humans for a much longer time than previously thought and that the evolution rate of B19V is an order of magnitude lower than previously estimated. Furthermore, we are able to date the recombination event that formed the second most common genotype of B19V. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics.

Satellite altimetry has shown that global mean sea level has been rising at a rate of ∼3 ± 0.4 mm/y since 1993. Using the altimeter record coupled with careful consideration of steric and glacial isostatic adjustment contributions, we show that this rate is accelerating at 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, which is consistent with climate model projections. If sea level continues to change at this rate and acceleration, sea-level rise by 2100 (∼65 cm) will be more than double the amount if the rate was constant at 3 mm/y. This has important implications for coastal communities that are vulnerable to sea-level rise. Continued monitoring of sea level with satellites, along with careful validation with in situ measurements, will be critical to accurately determining the rate and acceleration of sea-level rise.

We show that today’s midlife Americans have had more pain throughout adulthood than did today’s elderly. This is important because, if current patterns continue, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare. We also show that the gap in pain between the more and less educated has widened in each successive birth cohort. This is important because the increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. Thus, the mystery of American pain is not just a problem for the elderly.

NMR-assisted crystallography combines X-ray crystallography and solid-state NMR spectroscopy to characterize stable intermediates in enzyme active sites at atomic resolution. This approach is used here to characterize the α-aminoacrylate intermediate of tryptophan synthase, which is a defining species for β-elimination and replacement reactions catalyzed by pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes. The integrated structural information from NMR-assisted crystallography is used to understand why the enzyme substrate L-serine is replaced by the nonreactive analog benzimidazole in the active site, but unable to react further. This work is significant for mechanistic enzymology because it shows how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to identify structure–reactivity relationships that are not easily accessible by other means. The α-aminoacrylate structure also provides a snapshot of the chemical reactivity of the enzyme in the transition state leading to the product L-tryptophan.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV), continues to cause severe respiratory disease with a high case fatality rate. There are currently no licensed antiviral treatments for MERS. Remdesivir effectively inhibited MERS-CoV replication in human airway cultures and mice infected with the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV). Here, we tested the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the rhesus macaque model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir effectively prevented MERS-CoV−induced disease and virus replication when administered prior to infection, and provided a clear clinical benefit when treatment was initiated 12 h postinfection. These data support testing of remdesivir in the context of MERS clinical trials. It may also be considered for the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The mutualism between the bobtail squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a model system for studying host–microbe interactions. We show that the host provides the microbial symbionts with a critical nutrient on a diurnal cycle, and that the symbionts metabolize the nutrient to acidify their habitat at night. Acidification enhances the symbionts’ capacity to produce bioluminescence at night, which is important for the host’s communication with its predators and prey. This work suggests that the nutrient requirements of symbionts can be used by hosts to regulate the activity of their microbial communities, and that these communities can be fine-tuned to support host behaviors that occur on a daily cycle. This may be a widespread mechanism for controlling the activities of microbial communities in animals.

Growing suspension rates predict major negative life outcomes, including adult incarceration and unemployment. This study tests whether teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline—to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. This study also tests whether an empathic response to misbehavior would sustain students’ respect for teachers and motivation to behave well in class. Finally, a randomized field experiment tests a brief, online intervention to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic mindset about discipline. This intervention halved year-long student suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8% and bolstered respect the most at-risk students perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention.

Alkylated DNA lesions are among the most abundant DNA lesions that interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from RNA polymerase II (termed Pro-Gate loop), which plays an important role in transcriptional stalling and lesion bypass of alkylated DNA lesions. Importantly, the results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The identified Pro-Gate loop may also provide an opportunity for therapeutic intervention.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe respiratory disease in humans. The virus’s spike (S) glycoproteins are required for virus–cell receptor binding and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during virus production, and second after virus binding to cell receptors. We determined that the first cleavages are required for MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but are dispensable for infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. They also suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV’s restricted natural host range.

Achieving more plant-rich diets in higher income countries is vital for improving population health and protecting the natural environment. This paper provides robust evidence from a series of large-scale field experiments and observations that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in university catering outlets increased vegetarian sales by between 40.8 and 78.8%. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. The findings are highly relevant given that the foodservice sector is growing rapidly worldwide and is a major contributor to the environmental impact of food in many countries. The results are also highly relevant to the health implications of dietary change, given that plant-rich diets are associated with improved population health outcomes.

The cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. We applied quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We also complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed push for vote-by-mail in the United States. Advocates claim that vote-by-mail increases turnout and benefits Democrats, while critics allege that it depresses turnout and benefits Republicans. We analyze data from three US states that implemented vote-by-mail in a staggered fashion across counties, allowing us to estimate the causal effects of vote-by-mail on a county-by-county basis. We find that vote-by-mail increases turnout, but does not appear to benefit either major political party. These findings are robust to a variety of statistical and design-based robustness checks. Our results contradict many popular claims in the media and support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2. The rapid spread and severity of this disease has confounded the global medical community. Here, we present the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, an accessory protein that is rapidly evolving during the pandemic. The structure reveals two novel interfaces that form unique large-scale assemblies compared with SARS-CoV. These interfaces may be important for the unique immune evasion and suppression activities of SARS-CoV-2, and could be targeted for drug development. Additionally, the rapid evolution of ORF8 may be a contributing factor to the emergence of new COVID-19 variants, and understanding this evolution is important for predicting the course of the pandemic. This structure is a key milestone in understanding the molecular basis of COVID-19.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, but its underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. The effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε in cultured primary astrocytes, and the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. In conclusion, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema.

Data analysis is the art and science of extracting useful information from data. The data analyst is like a prospector searching for gold in a river. The challenge is that the gold may be mixed in with a lot of dirt and other debris. The analyst uses statistical methods to sift through the data, removing the “noise” and highlighting the “signal.” But the analyst must be careful not to fool herself. She may be tempted to use methods that amplify the signal, but these methods also amplify the noise. She must use methods that control for this amplification. We describe some new methods that address this challenge and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

Endothelial cell (EC) transplantation is a promising therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders. However, the generation of ECs has become increasingly important for providing vascular plexus to regenerated organs, such as the liver. Here, by screening 18 transcription factors that are important for both endothelial and hematopoietic development, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone directly converts primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs may provide a new cell source for vascularization in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) have oncogenic potential, and their physiological ligands, ALKAL1 and ALKAL2, were recently identified. Here, we show that zebrafish contain three related ligands, termed augmentors (aug-α1, aug-α2, and aug-β). Deficiency in any of the three ligands results in strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish. We show that aug-α1 and aug-α2 are essential for embryonic iridophore development and adult body coloration. In contrast, aug-α2 and aug-β are essential for iridophore formation in the adult eye. Importantly, these processes are entirely mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentors and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation.

This study revealed a function of stimulator of interferon genes (STING) in the regulation of β-cell function and glucose homeostasis. Specifically, β-cell–specific loss of STING impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, leading to glucose intolerance. Mechanistically, STING deficiency decreased expression of genes responsible for insulin secretion, and altered the transcription factor landscape, including loss of Pax6 nuclear localization, contributing to defective insulin secretion in STING-deficient β-cells. These findings are significant because they establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Thus, our study provides insights into the role of STING in the development of type 2 diabetes. Furthermore, targeting STING may be a potential strategy to improve β-cell function.

Influenza A viruses cause annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus and demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells, is required for optimal viral replication, and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The interaction we identified is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments promote selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions.

The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. Recent studies have demonstrated significant roles of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Our results provide mechanistic insights into the role of YAP/TAZ in atherogenesis and the potential therapeutic target for cardiovascular diseases.

The role of lightning in starting wildfires has long been emphasized in the United States. Our analysis of over 1.5 million government records of wildfires shows that human-started wildfires are far more common than lightning-started wildfires, and that human-started wildfires disproportionally occur when fuels are wetter, thereby expanding the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Human-started wildfires were dominant (>80% of ignitions) in over 5.1 million km2, the vast majority of the United States, whereas lightning-started fires were dominant in only 0.7 million km2, primarily in sparsely populated areas of the mountainous western United States. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The use of natural repellents for pest control is an eco-friendly and sustainable strategy. However, the molecular mechanisms of how natural repellents target arthropods remain largely unknown. Here, by using a behavior-guided screening of the genome of the Chinese redtail scorpion, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. Our study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. We anticipate that our study will trigger a new round of research on the molecular basis of arthropod–plant interactions, which is critical for the sustainable development of our ecosystem.

The recent emergence of Zika virus (ZIKV) as a human pathogen has prompted a need to understand the virus’s biology, including its replication dynamics. Using a mathematical model, we characterize the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection in macaques. Our analysis of the available data suggests that the virus replicates rapidly, that a large number of virions are produced per infected cell, and that the eclipse phase is short. We also assess the impact of antiviral treatment on the course of infection, which can accelerate the loss of viral RNA from the plasma. Our results can be used to assess the impact of antiviral treatment on ZIKV infection. The data-fitting analysis approach can be applied to other viruses for which data are becoming available.

Coral reefs are threatened by global warming. Mass bleaching events, in which the symbiotic algae are expelled from the coral, have become more frequent and severe. However, we still do not understand why bleaching occurs, which makes it difficult to predict the fate of coral reefs. Here, we show that heat stress causes a shift in the way nutrients are cycled within the coral–algal symbiosis, which gradually leads to a breakdown of the symbiosis. This is a major advance in our understanding of the causes of bleaching, and it may help to uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This knowledge is essential to assess the vulnerability of coral reefs to climate change and to design effective strategies for their conservation.

The intestinal epithelium forms a tight barrier to the environment. In Drosophila, the epithelium regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. We show that in a Drosophila intestinal tumor model, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis. Our experiments identify a feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Similar mechanisms may be at play in mammalian systems.

Breast cancers that recur after treatment with chemotherapy may be enriched for cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we find that the expression of ROR1, a type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor, increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with paclitaxel, which also enhanced expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Expression of ROR1 also enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. The end of the last glacial period was marked by a sudden ∼192-y series of massive halogen-rich volcanic eruptions from Mount Takahe, Antarctica, that coincided with the onset of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere. Sulfur isotope anomalies and marked decreases in bromine in ice cores consistent with increased surface UV radiation link the eruptions to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly led to the observed acceleration in glacial melting through changes in Southern Hemisphere westerlies and climate similar to modern springtime Antarctic ozone depletion. This finding implies that volcanism, in addition to changes in ocean circulation, atmospheric CO2, and insolation, may have played a role in the end of the last ice age.

Inland fisheries are a critical source of nutrition and employment for hundreds of millions of people. We provide the first global map of riverine fishery catches, which are highly concentrated in the most biodiverse and anthropogenically stressed river basins. The spatial coincidence of productive freshwater fisheries and high rates of food insecurity underscores the critical role of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors undermines efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our results can inform efforts to improve fishery management and protect both food security and species diversity. We recommend that future research focus on better understanding the linkages between fishing pressure, livelihoods, and environmental quality in freshwater ecosystems.

Realization of high-energy and safe aqueous Li-ion batteries is highly desired for applications in portable electronics, electric vehicles, and large-scale energy storage. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes imposes a limitation on the selection of negative electrode materials that can be used without triggering decomposition of water. Herein, a type of negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte. The ability of the adult mammalian central nervous system to regenerate lost neurons or axons is extremely limited. However, lesioning of sensory neurons in many species triggers an increase in the size of the dendritic arbor. Here, we show that the same neurons also regenerate their axons ectopically in response to the same lesion. These two forms of neuronal outgrowth are remarkably similar to two forms of regeneration observed in Caenorhabditis elegans, one of which is independent of the regeneration factor DLK-1. We also show that one of the genetic mechanisms underlying C. elegans regeneration and the mammalian mechanism of enhancing regeneration in the adult brain are similar. Our study reveals fresh molecular insights into the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

Meiotic recombination is a fundamental process for all sexually reproducing organisms, yet the underlying mechanisms are still not completely understood. Using a large population genomic dataset of the wild monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, we were able to precisely locate over 400,000 boundaries of historic crossovers or gene conversion tracts. Their distribution reveals hotspots of varying strengths, interspersed with cold regions of undetectably low recombination. Recombination rates peak near starts of genes and fall off sharply, exhibiting polarity. Recombination tracts are more likely to terminate in exons than in introns. The general pattern is similar to that observed in yeast, as well as in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

Resting state networks (RSNs) are defined as spatially coherent patterns of temporal correlations in functional MRI signals. Here, we used [18F]FDG-PET to identify reproducible RSN topographies in healthy subjects and in patients with Parkinson’s disease (PD) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). In healthy subjects, the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in PD this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern, which was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In AD, the default mode network was already significantly disrupted at diagnosis. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal PET scans from PD and AD subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction, whereas in AD significant reductions were already present at diagnosis. These results have implications for the clinical application of RSN analysis.

A major finding of this study is that nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA is not limited to bacteria but is also found in eukaryotes. NAD-RNA was found on a subset of mitochondrial and nuclear mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Because NAD-RNA was found on pre-messenger RNA transcripts, it is likely that NAD-RNA is cotranscriptionally generated. The presence of NAD-RNA on specific mRNAs may modulate RNA stability and translation in eukaryotes. The identification of NAD-RNA in eukaryotic systems extends the biological relevance of NAD+ beyond its well-known role as a cofactor for enzymatic reactions. The discovery of NAD-RNA in mitochondria may also have implications for the role of NAD+ in mitochondrial function and disease.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive vs. conventional therapy lowered the risk of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study showed that the benefits of intensive therapy persisted over 10 y in the DCCT, a phenomenon known as metabolic memory. We show here that certain DNA methylation (DNA-me) differences observed in whole blood (WB) at the end of the DCCT persist for several years in the EDIC Study, and that the same is true for DNA-me differences in blood monocytes (Monos). We also show that high glucose induces persistent hypomethylation at thioredoxin-interacting protein, a known complication-associated gene, in cultured Monos. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Such epigenetic changes may serve as biomarkers of risk for future complications.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 and mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The development of this disease is still not completely understood, but psychological and biological factors are involved. Recently, the composition of the gut microbiota has been shown to be altered in psychiatric disorders. Here, we show that alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of alcohol craving, anxiety, and depression. We also found that gut permeability is linked to a specific alteration in the gut microbiota. Finally, we show that the gut barrier and the microbiota are reversible after a short-term detoxification program. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is one of the most important model plants and crops, and tomato fruit flavor is one of the most important quality parameters. The present work elucidates the biosynthetic pathway for a major class of tomato fruit flavor compounds, namely the nitrogenous volatiles. These compounds are present in high amounts in tomato fruit, but are nearly absent in closely related species, indicating that the pathway is specific for the tomato clade. We identified a single gene essential for the biosynthesis of these volatiles, and we show that the encoded enzyme is a tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid N-hydroxylase that sequentially hydroxylates its substrates. This work is a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving tomato flavor quality. Moreover, it provides a model for the biosynthesis of other heterocycle-containing natural products.

The loss of biodiversity and the threat of global warming are two of the most important issues facing the planet today. However, we have little understanding of how these two threats interact. Here we show that temperature change systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning in microbial communities. The key findings were that more diverse communities were required to maintain ecosystem functioning as temperatures departed from ambient conditions, and that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) contains neurons that encode spatial information about the local environment, including grid cells, head-direction cells, border cells, and object-vector cells. The relationship between these cell types is currently unclear. Here, we used miniature, portable two-photon microscopes to examine the anatomical organization of these cell types in the superficial layers of MEC and parasubiculum while mice roamed freely in an open field. We found that grid cells were anatomically segregated from other spatially modulated cell types and tended to cluster, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells intermingled. These results suggest that grid cells form a distinct network that is largely separate from the other spatially modulated cell types. This work was enabled by the development of miniature, portable two-photon microscopes that allow mice to behave naturally.

Dodders are root- and leafless parasitic plants that have lost the ability to carry out photosynthesis and have to rely on their host plants for nutrients and water. Remarkably, some dodder species, e.g., Cuscuta australis, are able to synchronize their flowering with the flowering of their hosts. Here, we show that host-synthesized FT signals are able to move into dodder stems, where they physically interact with a dodder FD transcription factor to activate dodder flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host.
