The dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system and its return striatonigral pathway form a loop that is essential for the functions of dopamine in modulating movement and mood. Here, we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual arborizations innervating clusters of dopamine-containing neurons and their ventrally extending, tightly bundled dendrites. Within these formations (termed “striosome–dendron bouquets”), striosomal axons and dopamine-containing dendrites are intimately intertwined, as are other afferent and glial elements. The striking selectivity of striosomal output to the bouquets suggests that the bouquets could exert powerful and focused control within the dopamine system and the nigro–striato–nigral loop under normal conditions and could be critical to dysfunction in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease.

The feeling that two people “click” is one of the most robust and desired social experiences, yet we lack an understanding of how it emerges. Here we show that people feel more connected when their conversation partner responds quickly to them. This effect is determined primarily by partner responsivity rather than by how quickly people respond to their partner. Thus, the feeling that two people click is determined primarily by how responsive one person is to the other, and this signal can be determined honestly and rapidly (i.e., without conscious control) by listeners. These findings suggest that rapid partner responsivity comprises a sufficient signal of connection. This model provides a foundation for understanding how people might be trained to increase their social connection.

Cardiac pacemaker function is governed by the sinoatrial node (SAN), which is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes (SANCs). SANCs integrate membrane clock events with internal Ca2+ clock events to generate rhythmic depolarizations. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels are selectively expressed in SANCs. Deletion of STIM1 in SANCs disrupted SR Ca2+ homeostasis, leading to SAN dysfunction. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These studies have important implications for understanding the etiology of cardiac arrhythmia.

The role of silicon (Si) in plant defense against insect herbivores is well documented, but the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Here, we show that Si enhances resistance to rice leaffolder (Cnaphalocrocis medinalis) in rice by activating jasmonate (JA)-induced defense responses. Transcripts encoding defense marker genes and activities of defense enzymes increased in Si-pretreated rice plants after leaffolder attack. Silencing of allene oxide synthase and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 genes resulted in reduced Si accumulation and Si cell expansion in leaves and reduced the beneficial effects of Si pretreatment on rice resistance to leaffolder larvae. These findings suggest that JA promotes Si accumulation and that Si activates JA-induced defense responses, leading to enhanced resistance to insect herbivores. This study sheds light on the molecular mechanisms underlying Si-induced plant defense and the role of Si in the rhizosphere. The findings have implications for sustainable agriculture and environmental sustainability.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not fully understood. Here we show that it is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme that converts alkylglycerols to alkylglycerol-3-ols, which are further converted to alkylglycerol-3-phosphate and finally degraded to glycerone phosphate and the corresponding alcohol. We found intracellular alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity to be an important regulator of alkylglycerol metabolism in intact murine macrophages. The cellular lipidome was markedly changed in a parallel way by modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase expression and of tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. They reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing involves the ability to store and integrate pieces of information in working memory over short periods of time. According to the dominant view, information is maintained through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. Single neuron responses are dependent on experience, and we show through simulations that these adaptive changes in excitability provide memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. On this account, spiking activity writes information into coupled dynamic variables that control adaptation and move at slower timescales than the membrane potential. These variables can be used to predict neural responses to linguistic stimuli. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of functional biomolecules to plants is a major challenge for basic research and has implications for agriculture. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver functional RNA into plants. This is significant because DNA nanostructures are biocompatible, can be designed to be stable in biological media, and can be engineered to be internalized into plant cells. We show that the size, shape, and stiffness of the DNA nanostructure, as well as the location of the RNA cargo, can affect the internalization and gene silencing efficiency. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for plant cell delivery, which can be used to develop a new generation of plant transformation methods and can be extended to other biomolecules and other plants. This will have implications for agriculture and basic research.

Nutrient loading from tributary streams and rivers is a major driver of coastal eutrophication worldwide. However, most monitoring and regulatory efforts focus on larger tributaries, largely ignoring the many small streams that drain directly into coastal waters. We show that small streams can have high nutrient loads, especially when compared to their size, and that these loads are highly enriched in forms of nitrogen and phosphorus that are most available to algae. These streams are likely to disproportionately contribute to nearshore eutrophication, an underappreciated threat to coastal ecosystems worldwide. Our findings suggest that expanding nutrient management efforts to include smaller watersheds could help mitigate the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on coastal ecosystems.

Living systems are sustained by the continual absorption of environmental energy. However, the energy sources that sustain life are often difficult to access, requiring complex and finely tuned biochemical networks to extract and harness their power. In this article, we study a simple in silico model of a chemical system in an environment that provides access to strong thermodynamic forcing only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. These results suggest that the proper orchestration of many distinct catalytic actors may be a necessary feature of any self-sustaining dissipative system.

Antibodies against NMDA receptors (NMDARs) cause a severe autoimmune encephalitis with a wide range of neurological symptoms, including seizures. However, how blocking this excitatory synaptic receptor can lead to seizures is poorly understood. Here, we show that NMDAR antibodies change intrinsic cortical connections and neuronal population dynamics to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. Our results offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR antibodies. Elucidating how antibodies alter brain function in this disease is critical for understanding the pathophysiology of autoimmune encephalitis and for developing targeted treatments. Our results also provide a proof of principle for a new approach to identify key parameters that predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities in other neurological disorders.

The mechanisms by which the Earth system responds to extreme C perturbations are poorly understood. Here, we present a combined proxy and modeling approach to investigate the impact of an extreme C perturbation that occurred during a paleo-icehouse. We show that the extreme C perturbation led to a rapid (<100 years) rise in atmospheric CO2 and a global warming of ∼3 °C, which was superimposed on a long-term icehouse state. The warming event triggered a major biodiversity nadir and led to widespread seafloor anoxia that persisted for hundreds of thousands of years. The combined proxy and modeling approach used here can be applied to other C perturbation events to improve our understanding of Earth’s response to anthropogenic climate change.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is a multistakeholder initiative that aims to reduce tropical forest loss from oil palm cultivation. We evaluate the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation and fire in Indonesian oil palm plantations. While certification lowered deforestation, it had no causal impact on peatland forest loss or fire occurrence. Moreover, most certification occurred in plantations with little remaining forest. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. These findings are relevant for other tropical commodities, such as soy and timber.

We report the discovery of a small molecule inhibitor of the exocyst complex, a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. Using a chemical genetic approach, we show that Endosidin2 binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex and inhibits exocytosis and related processes in both plant and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool for studying exocytosis and the exocyst complex. Furthermore, it offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. We also show that the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex is a druggable target in plants, which may lead to the development of new herbicides. This study demonstrates the value of chemical genetics in the discovery of new modes of action for herbicides and new targets for human therapeutics.

Sex determination (SD) and sexual dimorphism (SDD) are fundamental evolutionary processes, but the relationship between SD and SDD is not well understood. Species with polygenic SD (PSD) have multiple interacting SD alleles segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes and scenarios where sex genotype can be decoupled from gonadal sex. We show that PSD in cichlid fishes produces modular SDD and phenotypic variation in a newly acquired SD allele. The modularity of SDD produced by PSD provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of SD alleles in populations. Our results also have implications for understanding phenotypic variation in humans and other species with complex SD systems.

The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is challenged by two major risk factors for degeneration: light-induced oxidative stress from bisretinoids and intracellular Fe. Here we show that Fe chelation in RPE cells reduces oxidative stress, as measured by bisretinoid oxidation and cell death. Conversely, increasing Fe in RPE cells exacerbates bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. Light-independent degradation of bisretinoids by Fenton chemistry products was also observed. These findings are relevant to the development of therapeutics for Fe-related retinal disorders and to the impact of Fe on other light-exposed tissues. They also highlight the importance of Fe chelation in the management of Fe overload in the retina and other tissues.

Specialization is considered a “dead end” because it is assumed that morphological adaptations to a specific prey type constrain a predator to that same prey type. However, in siphonophores, a group of pelagic colonial animals that use specialized tentacles for prey capture, we found that specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. These findings challenge the assumption that specialization is a dead end, and contribute to understanding how present-day food webs have been shaped by morphological innovation and evolution. This study also provides a framework for analyzing the evolution of specialization in other predators.

The evolution of the human hand is a central topic in paleoanthropology. The fossil record of hand evolution is notoriously poor, however, especially for the time interval between 1.8 and 0.8 Mya. Here we report a metacarpal from a new East African Middle Pleistocene site that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. The distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding has important implications for understanding the evolution of human hand morphology and the relationship between tool use and hand morphology.

Cancer cells have increased demand for purines and pyrimidines, which are synthesized using one-carbon units from tetrahydrofolate. We show that dual inhibitors of the enzymes serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2) block tumor growth in vivo, and are particularly cytotoxic to B-cell cancers in vitro. We reveal that the mechanism for paradoxical sensitivity of B-cell lines to SHMT inhibition is a defect in glycine import, which can be exploited therapeutically. Thus, we have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell cancers, and developed a small-molecule inhibitor to exploit it. These findings may lead to new treatments for B-cell cancers, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which has a 5-y survival of 25%. The inhibitor may also be useful for targeting tumor growth in general.

This study finds a causal link between deforestation and people’s dietary quality, and the results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study is significant because it uses a modeling approach that combines two-way fixed-effects regression analysis with covariate balancing generalized propensity score (CBGPS) weighting, allowing for causal inferences to be made. The study is also significant because it uses high-quality, nationally representative survey data from Tanzania to examine the links between deforestation and people’s dietary quality. Few studies have been able to make causal inferences about the links between forests and nutrition outcomes. The study is also significant because it examines the impacts of both deforestation and forest fragmentation.

Mechanization has been a key technology for the expansion of agriculture and feeding growing populations. However, the weight of modern harvesters now approaches that of the heaviest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, raising the paradoxical question of potential prehistoric soil compaction. We show that surface contact stresses of farm vehicles have remained nearly constant over the course of mechanization, but the increase in vehicle capacity has led to a dramatic rise in soil stresses, with chronic risk of soil compaction now affecting 20% of global arable land. This trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic soil mechanical limits. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have led to similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. Ecological strategies for reducing soil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
